clips.description: Marcus on pricing his first big piece and realizing he was losing money
clips.transcriptSnippet: I quoted $200 for a full sleeve session and it took me 8 hours. I made $25 an hour. My barber makes more than that. That was my wake-up call.

clips.description: Sarah on how raising prices actually increased her bookings
clips.transcriptSnippet: When I raised my rate from $120 to $200 an hour, I thought I'd lose half my clients. Instead, I got BETTER clients. People who valued the work, showed up on time, tipped well. The cheap clients were the most difficult ones anyway.

clips.description: Marcus Rodriguez on pricing strategy for a premium brand
clips.transcriptSnippet: I don't negotiate. Ever. My price is my price. If someone asks for a discount, I politely say: 'I understand budgets are real. Here are some great artists who work at a lower price point.' And I refer them. No hard feelings. But I never devalue my own work.

content.presenterNotes: Play each clip, then pause for 3-5 seconds to let it land. After each clip, add brief host commentary tying it back to the pricing theme. After the last clip: 'Three different artists, same lesson: know your worth and don't apologize for it.'
